data.title: Anonymous class missing references / missing in implementations
Allow Close Command Palette with the Click of the Mouse
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.0 - Insiders (74f5073, Date 2017-07-12T05:15:55.615Z)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Settings:
`workbench.quickOpen.closeOnFocusLost: false`

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

As seen with @bpasero  in this issue #30495 .

Allow the Command Palette to be closed by clicking anywhere in the VSCode:

- navigate between Active Bar options;
- in the menu bar (until you do not choose an option it can continue to be active). Example:
1. Press F1 to activate the Command Palette;
2. Go to 'File> Preferences> Settings'.
3. When you open Settings, the Command Palette remains open, but the correct one would be to close it;

- For the options in the Status Bar, the same switch the focus to clicked option (as it currently does)
<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Context menu for unsaved buffers not appearing after selecting one buffer for compare
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:36:31.751Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
plsql|cas|0.0.3



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Launch VS Code
2.  Create a new file (File --> New)
3.  Write some example text in the "Untitled-1" buffer (e.g. "Test123")
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30127452/28136565-668c982c-6707-11e7-9c69-c61624d162ee.png)

4.  Create a second new file (File --> New)
5.  Write some example text (that differs from your example text in step 4) in the "Untitled-2" buffer (e.g. "Test234")
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30127452/28136599-821fe72e-6707-11e7-8afa-d61aa7de0ff1.png)

6.  Open the context menu for the "Untitled-1" buffer (Right Click on "Untitled-1")

7.  Click "Select for Compare"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30127452/28136624-9974979e-6707-11e7-863d-01d09432295b.png)

8.  Attempt to open the context menu for "Untitled-2" (Right click on "Untitled-2").  The context menu will fail to appear for any unmodified buffers in the "Open Editor" menu pane.



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fenced JavaScript in markdown adds ">" when you type "<"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T18:36:31.751Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
jshint|dba|0.10.15
vscode-todo-parser|min|1.8.10
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6
language-liquid|nei|0.0.2
vscode-jest|Ort|2.2.0

---

Writing a less-than sign automatically adds a greater-than sign after it. The update seems to have caused this as I have never had an issue with it before.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type a fenced JavaScript code block like:
````markdown
```javascript

```
````
2. Type a `<` inside the fence.
3. It will add a `>` after the `<` you typed resulting in:
````markdown
```javascript
<>
```
````

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: PHP: Incorrect syntax highlighting in Class::constant
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.0 (b8cd5b9556d8b70ea560d35b903422363f6c5c40, 2017-07-10T20:36:40.018Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.10.0-26-generic
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
codeception-snippets|die|0.0.4
githistory|don|0.2.1
php-debug|fel|1.11.1
php-intellisense|fel|1.4.3
AWK|lug|0.0.2
ftp-sync|luk|0.3.3
mads|mir|0.0.5
HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3
vscode-icons|rob|7.10.1
code-spell-checker|str|1.2.1



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set color theme "Dark+ (default dark)"
2. Use the expression `Headers::MCONTENT` anywhere in PHP code
3. See color of `Headers`

Expected result:

- green (IMHO the same color as in definition of class)

Actual result:

- white
![selection_030](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12584138/28131191-721e2caa-6739-11e7-8cd7-afcbe31e89ae.png)

It's a **regression** in vscode 1.14. It worked well in 1.13.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature: Keyboard Shortcut to Skip Preview Using Quick Open
data.body:
I almost always use Quick Open (Ctrl/Command + P) to open my files. Sometimes I want to open multiple files, but they open in Preview by default when using the Quick Open.

I know that there is a user setting that allows you to disable Preview, but 85% of the time I enjoy the Preview.

This is a feature request to add a keyboard shortcut to open the selected file in Quick Open and skip Preview mode. The default behavior on Enter should still open it in Preview mode.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10/elementary OS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open "Quick Open" view using Ctrl (or Command) + P
2. Type in a name
3. Press Enter
4. Verify that files is open in Preview mode

data.title: Autocomplete/Intellisense Does Not Show All Options For Object Value
data.body:
<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.5

Autocomplete/intellisense is not showing all the options for an object that goes into a function parameter even though it is defined in a typescript interface.

Example:
```
interface Fruit {
    /** Returns a fruit color. */
    getFruitColor(options: { fruit: 'apple' | 'orange' }): string;
    getFruitColor(options: { fruit: 'banana' }): boolean;
}

function testFunction (fruit: Fruit) {
    let color = fruit.getFruitColor({ fruit: '' }); // <-- Autocomplete only shows apple and orange as options and not banana
}
```
![screen shot 2017-07-12 at 10 27 36 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15164008/28125639-cae175a6-66ec-11e7-813c-22a579c65554.png)

It appears that only the first method's options object is getting indexed by VS autocomplete but not the second one.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Add the ability to control if the nodejs console window closes on exit of the node app.
data.body:
_From @paulvanbrenk on June 21, 2017 19:36_

Add the ability to control if the nodejs console window closes on exit of the node app.

Based on the exit code, we would like the following options.

* `both` always keeps the console open
* `normal` keeps the console open when the exit code is `0`
* `abnormal` keeps the console open when the exit code is not `0`
* `default` close the console, when the app exits



_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-node-debug2#113_

data.title: Dim or otherwise indicate "inactive" editor/terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: One of the best features of VS Code is the built-in terminal. However, I often begin typing in the editor when in fact I think I'm in the terminal - and vice versa. To alleviate this issue, it would be helpful to visually indicate which portion of the IDE is "active" vs. "inactive". A subtle dimming effect might just do the trick.

data.title: Provide inline actions to side-by-side/inline diff view like git merge
data.body:
In last June release, inline merge actions were provided for git merge markers within the editor-
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/751732/29218899-314ce20a-7ed8-11e7-839c-3113d226a28f.png)

Requesting for similar inline actions through code lense in side-by-side and inline general diff editor. The code actions can be "Take from left side" or "Take original", "Next" and "Previous". And as copying original is prohibited in inline diff view, a "Copy original" option can also be added there.

data.title: VSCode as difftool does not work without --wait
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14 insiders
- OS Version: OSX El capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

1. configure vscode as difftool as explained here https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/versioncontrol
2. Remove the --wait option

For some reason that I'm unable to understand, VSCode can not be used as a git difftool if you remove the --wait option. What happens is that the vscode is opened with no content, no diff, no file, just like you were just clicking on its' icon. 
If you do `code --diff fileA fileB` directly on the console it works perfectly, but it fails if you run it directly from git.

- OS Version:Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1.create an HTML file
2.type a script tag `<script></script>`
3.when hit Enter before the `</script>` the indent is wrong, `</script>` should has the same indent with `<script>`
4 then hit the Enter after the `</script>`, the `</script>` will have no indent

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Move settings.json on mac to ~/.vscode
data.body:
Currently the user settings are located at `$HOME/Library/Application Support/Code/User/settings.json`. However when managing these settings in a dotfiles repo it's easier to manage if the settings are located directly in the users home directory or in a folder (say `~/.vscode`).

My suggestions would be `~/.vscode`, which would then also house `keybindings.json`, etc. Similar to atom's `~/.atom`

data.title: Make the compare action label easier to understand when file names are identical
data.body:
If I've selected a file `a.yaml` for comparison in multi-root folder `rootA` and use the context-menu on another file `b.yaml` in root folder `rootB`, then showing "Compare with `rootA/a.yaml`", i.e. adding the root path `rootA`, instead of just `a.yaml` would be helpful. 

cc #28344

data.title: [Features] Add Task keyboard shortcut
data.body: Unless I am missing it, I don't see any keyboard combination to bring up the tasks menu. There is a keyboard shortcut for the build task, but not the more general tasks. It would be great to have one.
